Fatuma is a married woman with three children. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and fees.
 
She has operated a tailoring business for the past four years. Her potential clients are ladies and gents. She dreams of establishing a big tailoring shop in the future. 

With the 50,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business.

loans.name: Rwad Group

texts.en:
The Rwad Group consists of four women from Al-Hodeida, Yemen. They asked for a loan of 100,000 YER [Yemen rials] to pay for purchasing woman's clothes, perfumes and incense. 

Araqia is 24 years old and a single woman. She lives with her family in the city of Al-Hodeida. Her family conditions are bad, so she has to help her family in paying for all living expenses. She is a door-to-door seller. She has been selling clothes for about a year. This business is making a good profit, so she decided to expand her business and start selling perfumes and incense. Therefore, she applied for a loan in the amount of 20,000 YER from AMB to buy clothes, perfumes and incense for resale to increase her profit.

loans.use: to buy clothes, perfumes and incense for resale to increase her profit.

loans.name: Lhagva

texts.en:
Mrs. Lhagva, a resident of the Bayanhoshuu area of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia, lives with her husband and a son in their house. Her husband, Narantuya, works at a local company as a security guard. Her son, Tsend-Ayush, is 26 and has just started his own business of natural water disbursement. 

Lhagva has been providing tailoring services since 1998. She is a very hardworking and talented woman who has been pleasing her clients over the years with her qualified service. She has been helping her son to start his business and dig a well on their plot of land. 

She is now requesting a loan of 6,000,000 MNT to purchase equipment and tools to start his natural water disbursement to local residents. She is a very responsible woman.

loans.use:
to purchase equipment and tools to start her
natural water disbursement to local residents.

loans.name: Ariel

texts.en:
Ariel is thankful for the financial assistance extended to him. He was able to buy the spare parts and accessories that his tricycle needed. He has this business for two years now. He was able to help his family with the income that he generated from his business.

He would like to apply for another PHP 17,000 loan  to buy other spare parts and to maintain his Tricycle unit. His profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain his daily needs. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

Ariel hopes to have another unit of tricycle, and he dreams of having a lifetime partner. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of their work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay their microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and maintain his tricycle unit.

loans.name: Fidelite Group

texts.fr: La cliente  Mongani est une conseillère du collectif de crédit « Fidélité », doyenne, senior entrepreneur expérimentée, dynamique, âgée de 64 ans et mère de 8 enfants qui sont déjà mariés et ont tous leurs foyers. Son conjoint un chauffeur auprès d’une compagnie privée. La cliente est une vendeuse des boissons. Elle installe ses produits à son domicile. Elle commença ses affaires avec  l’assistance de son époux. Plus tard, elle bénéficia le prêt de l’IMF Hekima. Il ya 30 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité.  Ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d’acheter 70 casiers de boissons (30 casiers de Primus, 20 casiers de Fanta, 10 casiers de Skol, 10 casiers de Mutzig). Ainsi, elle souhaite étendre son projet de commerce et passer le reste de sa vie en paix. La vente en crédit et les pertes de change sont de défis pour le développement de son activité. Au finish, elle remercie fortement Hekima pour l’autonomisation des femmes entrepreneurs non bancables, surtout ; pendant ce moment critique de guerre à l’Est du pays.
texts.en: Mongani is the leader of the «Fidelité » savings group. She is a seasoned, experienced and energetic entrepreneur. She is 64 years old and has eight children, who are already married and have their own household. Her husband works as a driver for a private company. Mongani sells beverages. She sets up her wares by her home. She has launched her business with help from her husband. Later on, she obtained a loan from Hekima. She has been in this business for 30 years. This new loan will allow her to buy 70 cases of beverages (30 cases of Primus beer, 20 cases of Fanta, 10 cases of Skol beer, and 10 cases of Mutzig beer). Eventually she would like to fold her business and be able to enjoy her retirement. Her main challenges are selling on credit and currency exchange losses. Finally, she sincerely thanks Hekima for helping female entrepreneuers who do not have access to traditional banking become financially independent, especially at this critical moment while there is warfare in the east of the country.

loans.use: to buy 70 cases of various beverages.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Mwanalima

texts.en:
Mwanalima is a married woman and has been blessed with four children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling household consumables like wheat flour, rice and cooking oil. She cites seasonality as her major challenge in the business. 

She is requesting 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to boost her kiosk, purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat

loans.name: Avtandil

texts.en:
Avtandil is 56 years old. He lives in the village of Kveda Sazano with his wife, two sons, daughter-in-law and a grandchild. Avtandil has chronic health problems and gets small-sized assistance from the government. 

In spite of his health problems, Avtandil works hard and is busy with agricultural activities. Specifically, he owns a vineyard and grows walnut trees in his plot of land. He works hard the whole year and harvests the quality products which are sold to retailers. Additionally, the family runs an animal husbandry business and breeds two pigs. 

The family lives below the poverty line, and according to government estimates, they belong to “vulnerable poor” category. 

With this loan, Avtandil would like to purchase a tractor. He will use it to perform agricultural work on the land of nearby farmers, mainly in the tilling and sowing seasons, and will be paid by the landlords. He will save any profits generated by the tractor and continue to cultivate his own land. His son will assist him in this business as well. He expects that this loan will significantly increase his family's income and enable him to provide better living conditions for his family.

loans.use: to purchase a tractor to perform work on the land of nearby farmers.

loans.name: Leona

texts.en:
This is Leona. She previously accessed a 14,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in their personal, household and business expenditures. For additional income, she also sells different groceries and toiletries.
 
She would like to apply for another 14,000 PHP loan to buy different beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and the children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Leona dreams of being more successful in her business and hopes to help her grandchildren with their schooling. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week. This is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for different beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en: Elisa is running an entertainment business, offering music through VideoKey. She has been in this business for more than four years and she has earned well to help cover their needs. Recently, she joined GDMPC and taken out a loan to buy a new microphone for the VideoKey machine. As an aid to her husband's income, she has to find ways in order to entertain her customers. In the future, she wants to expand her business and become a successful entrepreneur.

loans.use: to buy a new microphone for the VideoKey machine.

loans.name: Angelie

texts.en:
Angelie has run a general store for more than five years to earn a living. She is married, with one child. Aside from this, she also serves food in her cafeteria, and she earned an extra income for the family. 

Recently, she borrowed from GDMPC microcredit to buy more grocery goods for her store. She plans to used her revenue as additional capital to expand her business. 

In the future, Angelie wants to improve the general living of her entire family.

loans.use: to buy more grocery goods for her store

loans.name: Charo

texts.en:
Charo appreciates his previous Kiva loan, which improved his living standards and enabled him to earn a higher income from his motorcycle business.

He is now requesting a loan of KES 30,000 to purchase spare parts and paint his motorcycle.  He thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and paint his motorcycle

loans.name: Erhemmart

texts.en:
Erhemmart is 32 and lives with her husband and a daughter in a small house in the Bayanhoshuu area of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her husband runs a taxi service business in town and her daughter is a local school student. 

Erhemmart has been working as a saleswoman in a local market for years and started her business in a rental booth of the local market in 2005. She has been providing qualified organic fruits to local residents. She purchases from wholesalers and agriculturalists in large amounts from a bigger market. 

She is now requesting a loan of 5,000,000 MNT to purchase an eco-friendly, electric and fuel consuming hybrid car to reduce her transportation costs. She is a well-organized and hardworking woman.

loans.use: to purchase an eco-friendly, electric and fuel consuming hybrid car to reduce her transportation costs.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
At the age of 31, Edward is still single. He finished college but was not given a chance for employment. However, he did not fail to find other sources of income in order to help his parents improve their life. Despite being unemployed, Edward earns income by running a bakery business in their village. He said that his type of business is laborious, but being patient and loving of the work is easy for him to manage. 

Edward wishes for a loan of PHP 40,000 to buy raw ingredients for baking breads. He has been almost five years in the business and hopes that it will last so he can still manage the business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for baking breads.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a widow and a mother of two children who attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water.

She sells fruits and green vegetables. She always struggles to improve her grocery stall, trying to sell more and save money to support her family. She is requesting a loan to buy sacks of fruits and green vegetables for resale.

loans.use: to buy sacks of fruits and green vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Adolfo

texts.en: Adolfo is married with three children. He runs a service-based business providing motor transportation services. Adolfo carries passengers and baggage to different destinations to earn a living and as an aid to his income from farming. Adolfo joined GDMPC recently and borrowed a loan to buy motor accessories and tires. He wants to make sure of the good service he provides to his costumers. In the future, he wants to improve the general living situation of his family.

loans.use: to buy motor accessories and tires.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 49 years old and widowed, with four children. She runs a charcoal business in Tombo, a western rural area in Freetown. She started her business because she wanted to generate a permanent source of income.  

She's been in this business since the death of her husband during the rebel war and she sells charcoal at her house. She describes her major hardships as inadequate funds to run her business and transportation problems.  

Fatmata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone Microfinance Company Limited to purchase more charcoal, to expand her business. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and improve her level of living. 

In the future, she would like to change her business to a food stand store. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal, to expand her business.

loans.name: Anelyn

texts.en:
This is Anelyn. She previously accessed a 25,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase merchandise items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in their personal, household and business expenditures.
 
She would like to apply for another 35,000 PHP loan for her to buy more merchandise items and products to increase her product inventory. The more items she has on display and available on hand, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. The profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her children’s education and daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Anelyn dreams to be more successful in business and hopes to give her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional supplies and merchandise products, like clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics, needed in her business.

loans.name: Sherly

texts.en:
Sherly is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her. She was able to buy more grocery items for her variety store, which she has run for five years now. Her loan also helped in the education of her child. Her income from business assisted in their everyday household expenditures. She and her partner are both working hard to provide for their family.

Sherly would like to apply for another loan, in the amount of PHP 10,000, to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell should result in greater profit. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her child’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Sherly hopes that her business will flourish and she dreams that her child will finish his studies. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business. There, she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Wara

texts.en:
Meet 32-year-old Wara, from Tombo, a western, rural area in Freetown. She is married, with three children between the ages of five years and 15 years. Two of her children are going to school. 

After the war, Wara established her wax cotton business. She began her business because she needed to create income to support the home. She works at the business ten hours per day and seven days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is lack of enough capital to run her business.

Wara requires a loan in order to buy more wax cotton for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her standard of living. 

In the future, Wara plans to own a big shop. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more wax cotton for resale.

loans.name: Pilika Pilika Group

texts.en:
Anselmina, who is in her late 50s, is single, with four children who have finished school. 

For three years now, she has been running a business, selling new clothes. Anselmina works from  6am to 4pm each working day and is able to make very good monthly returns.

This will be her first loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania, which she will use to buy clothes stock for her business. Anselmina, who is selling her clothes up-country, dreams to open a big clothes shop, so as to move away from door-to-door selling. 

Anselmina will share this loan with her loan  group, Pilika Pilika Group, which totals four members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy clothes stock for her business.

loans.name: Sheryl

texts.en:
Sheryl is 32 years old and married, with five children.

Sheryl works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and she has requested a PHP 29,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Sheryl has borrowed and repaid twelve loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for seven years and she also earns an income from farming sugarcane and selling fruits and vegetables.

Sheryl aspires to save enough money, so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Flordelina

texts.en: Flordelina is married with four children. She runs a general store to add to her husband's income from employment. She also sells food and snacks in town. She borrowed a loan from GDMPC micro credit to buy additional grocery goods to sell. She plans to save money for the future needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
This is Riza. She previously accessed a 25,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts, accessories and for the maintenance of their tricycle unit. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children, and their personal household, and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of their tricycle unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs and her children's education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Riza dreams to have another tricycle unit and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week.  This is also where she can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis.  A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners.  The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, to build social capital and to pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and maintenance of her tricycle.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret appreciates her previous Kiva loan, which improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her cloth-selling business and earn a higher income.

She is now requesting a loan of KES 40,000 to purchase more bales of clothes for resale . She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Meet 27-year-old Fatmata from Tombo Western rural area in Freetown. She is married with 3 children aged 2 years and 12 years old. Two of her children are going to school. After the war, Fatmata established her fish business. She began her business because she needed to earn income to support her household. She works at the business 10 hours per day and 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is lack of enough capital to run it.

Fatmata requires a loan in order to buy more fish for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, Fatmata plans have a fishing boat for herself. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more fish for resale

loans.name: Chuchi

texts.en:
Chuchi is 60 years old and married with three children. Chuchi works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 29,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Chuchi has borrowed and repaid eleven loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for six years and also earns an income from soft-drink retail. Chuchi aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is 42 years old, married, and has four children, three of whom attend school. She buys and sells recycled materials in the Philippines, which she has been doing for 10 years.

Elsie is requesting a loan from NWTF for 27,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase more stocks of scrap and recycled materials to sell. In the future, she would like to save money to buy a delivery truck for her business.

loans.use: to purchase scrap and recycled materials

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 53 years old and married with three children.

Rosemarie works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Rosemarie has borrowed and repaid 21 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 32 years and also earns income from food vending.

Rosemarie aspires to save money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en:
This is Eufemia. She previously accessed an 25,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts, accessories, and for maintenance on their Jeepney unit. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household, and business expenditures.
 
She would like to apply for another 27,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and for maintenance on their Jeepney unit. Profits from her business will definitely help sustain her family's daily needs and her children's education. She looks forward to this additional income with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Eufemia hopes to buy another unit of Jeepney and dreams to give her children a good life and education. She meets with her co-fellowship members** every week to share stories of her work and to find strength and encouragement from the word of God, which she studies.

* Curiously, Jeepneys have purely American origins. They were first used by American soldiers helping the Philippines throw off the invading Japanese. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater Jeepney. It is open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy enough for every day travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. Now, the Jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly the Philippines.

** All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts, accessories, and maintenance on her Jeepney unit.

loans.name: Marcela

texts.en:
Marcela's previous loan was a big help in her business and she is very thankful for it. Her loan helped her in her business and also in the education of her children. Her income from business assisted in meeting her family's everyday expenses at home. She is already a widow and that's why she works hard to provide for her family.

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and farm inputs needed in her pineapple farming business. Her profits from his business will definitely help her sustain her family's daily needs and support her children's education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Marcela dreams that her farm will be expanded so she will have more fruits to plant and harvest. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for fertilizer and farm inputs needed in her pineapple farming business

loans.name: Benita

texts.en:
Benita previously requested a loan for 15,000 PHP, which she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her child’s education and in their personal, household, and business expenditures.
 
Benita is requesting another loan for 20,000 PHP, which she will use to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. profit. Her profits from business will help sustain her family’s daily needs and child’s education expenses. 

Benita hopes to be more successful in her business and to become rich. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and to draw strength and inspiration from God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items, toiletries, and beverages

loans.name: Haja

texts.en:
Haja is 28 years old, married, and has two children. She operates a fish business in Tombo, the western rural area in Sierra Leone. She faces the challenge of slow sales during the rainy season.

Haja is requesting a loan from BRAC Sierra Leone, which she will use to purchase more fish to sell. The extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and take care of her family's welfare. In the future, she would like to expand her business to a higher level.

loans.use: to purchase fish

loans.name: Claris

texts.en:
Claris is married and has no children. She owns a house that has neither piped water nor electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She operates a tailoring business, making garments for both men and women. She cites seasonality as her major challenge and she dreams of establishing a boutique in the near future.

With the KES 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business

loans.name: Mbeyu

texts.en:
Mbeyu is a hard-working and enterprising woman who lives in the coastal region of Kenya.

Mbeyu has operated a clothes-selling business for the past two years. She sells door to door to her town to dwellers, passersby and neighbors. She faces a major challenge of inflation in her business. 

With the KES 30,000 loan, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Nasanmonh

texts.en: Mrs. Nasanmonh is 35 years old, and lives with her 2 sons in a Ger, a traditional nomadic tent, in the Bayanhoshuu area of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her sons go to local schools. Nasanmonh moved to Ulaanbaatar city in 1999 from Bulgan province where her parents still live. Her sons go there in the summertime to help their grandparents herd livestock. Nasanmonh's husband passed away a few years ago and now she takes care of the family by herself. Nasanmonh started her business soon after she came to the city. Her sewing machine is broken and she needs to replace it to continue her business. She is now requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase a sewing machine to continue her tailoring business. She is a hardworking, diligent, and strong lady.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine to continue her tailoring business

loans.name: Ilhomjon

texts.ru: Илхомчону 20 лет. Он имеет средне -специальное образование. Илхомджон 3 месяца назад поступил на работу в микро финансовое учреждение. Он хочет усовершенствовать свои знания. Он хочет получить высшее образование. Он поступил в университет на первый курс. Илхомджон учится в факультете Финансы и кредит. Он не женат и живет с родителями. Он запрашивает займ для оплаты учебного договора. Он ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en: Ilhomjon is 20 years old.  He has a secondary-specialized education.  Three months ago, Ilhomjon started a new job at a micofinancing organization.  He wants to improve his knowledge by obtaining a university education.  He has enrolled into the first year of the university program at the department of Finance and Loans.  He is not married and lives with his parents.  He is asking for a loan to pay for his tuition costs.  He is waiting for your kindness.

loans.use: To pay for university education

loans.name: Arshaluys

texts.en: Arshaluys is from the Malishka village in the Vayots Dzor region. She lives with her husband. Both of them work hard to meet their needs. Arshaluys works in the village local self-governance body, and her husband works in the private sector. To cover their expenses, they are also engaged in breeding  livestock--cows and hens--and cultivating apricots, apples, pears and walnuts. In the present,it is very difficult for the family to fully cover their needs. This is why Arshaluys wants to increase their livestock a little bit. She needs a loan of USD 2100 to purchase two steers and forage for them. She has already taken a loan from a local financial institution, but unfortunately wasn't able to pay it back. However, thanks to hard work during the recent times, Arshaluys was able to organize her farming in a sustainable way, ensuring that she will be able to cover the monthly payments. So, she has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Arshaluys and her husband rely on the good will of the lenders and will be thankful to them for helping them sustain their lives.

loans.use: to purchase two steers and forage for them

loans.name: Parvona

texts.ru: Парвона молодая бизнес леди. Ей 23 года. Она замужем, но не имеет детей. Она более 3 лет занимается собственным бизнесом. Парвона в основном выращивает картошку и пшеницу. После того как она собирает урожай, она продаёт свой товар на местном рынке с первых рук по более низкой цене. Ее муж помогает ей по введению бизнеса. Парвона постепенно развивает бизнес и усовершенствует свои знания. Парвона хочет отремонтировать свой дом, так как она живет в плохом жилищном условии. Парвона запрашивает займ на сумму 2000 сомони для покупки строительных материалов как цемент, краски и т.п. Она надеется на ваше милосердие.
texts.en:
Parvona is a young business woman.  She is 23 years old, married, but has no children.  For more than 3 years, she has been running her own business.  The bulk of her business involves growing potatoes and wheat.  After she collects the harvest, she sells it at the local market at competitive prices.  He husband helps her run the business.  Parvona has been steadily growing her enterprise and improving her knowledge of the subject.  

Parvona wants to make improvements on her house, since it is in need of repair.  Parvona is asking for a loan of 2000 somoni to purchase building materials such as cement and paint.  She is hoping for your generosity.

loans.use: To buy building materials such as cement and paints to repair her house

loans.name: Yealie

texts.en:
Yealie is 37 years old and married with three children. She runs a fish business in Tombo Western rural area in Sierra Leone. She started this business to make her daily living. 

She's been in this business from just after she got married and sells fish within her community. She says that at present, her business is doing well because out of the profits, she was able to take of her family.

Yealie requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more fish for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and have a permanent business location. In the future, she would like to expand her business to a higher level. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale.

loans.name: Anba Group

texts.en: The Anba group consists of four females from Hodeidah, Yemen. Aida, 40 years old, is a married woman who is responsible for two children. She has started her job creating homemade henna items, like mixing perfumes and creams which are used by brides for their wedding. She sells it to retailers, customers and door to door. Any shortages of her product items will cause her job to stop. That is why she has applied for a loan to buy the required henna items to continue her business. All members of the group are hoping to earn a good income, which will allow them to improve their families' quality of life.

loans.use: to buy the required henna items to continue her business.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a widowed man and with five children, two who attend school and the rest adults. He owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.

Peter has operated a cafe business making staples like rice, tea, beans, chapati (flat bread) for sale to passers-by and neighbours. He cited seasonality as a major challenge.

With the Kshs 50,000, he wants to purchase stock of goods, maize flour, wheat flour, rice and drinks for the business. He joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase stock of goods, maize flour, wheat flour, rice and drinks for the business.

loans.name: Kristina

texts.en:
Kristina is a first-year student at the American University of Central Asia, department of Business Administration and here is her story:

“I am happy to become part of the American University of Central Asia. For a long period of time, I couldn’t understand what I wanted to do in my life, but now I know for sure that I want to work in business. Business is an area that constantly changes. I love changes, actions and development. Business is something that really entrains me. I think becoming a professional in whatever you do is the main priority for any individual who wants to succeed in life. I believe that AUCA is the university that will help me reach my intention. I know that important goals are not achieved easily, but I’m ready to put a lot of effort in my future occupation. I’m ready to work hard and I’m sure it is worth it.

"This is a new stage that starts in my life. I hope it is going to be a fascinating lifelong journey that I want to start at AUCA, an American type of education has many advantages that are important for me. I like that I can choose additional courses there at AUCA. I will be able to take economics courses that I think will be helpful later on in business and some psychology courses that are in my opinion generally needed in life.

"AUCA gives many interesting and unique opportunities to its students and one of them is financial aid that is open to all its students. I would like to take an opportunity and apply for a Kiva loan, which will enable me to cover my higher education fees.”

loans.use: to pay for my higher education.

loans.name: Gagik

texts.en: Gagik is an experienced farmer from Getap village of Vayots Dzor village. He lives with his wife and son. Gagik earns a living for his family through renovating cars. Gagik's son works in the private sector. The two of them are the only breadwinners of the family. As it is hardly possible to meet the family's needs based on their salaries, Gagik and his family are involved in cattle breeding and agriculture, and in cultivation of apricots, cherries, apples, pears, and walnuts. They realize the agricultural products in the local market. To be able to continue his agribusiness in a sustainable way, Gagik needs a loan of USD 3000 to purchase calves and to buy some forage for cattle. He has taken a loan from a local financial institution before, but unfortunately wasn't able to return it back. However, thanks to hard work during the recent times, Gagik was able to run his agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that he will be able to cover the monthly payments. So, he has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Gagik and his family will be thankful to all the lenders for helping them to maintain their agribusiness.

loans.use: to purchase calves and to buy some forage for cattle.

location.town: Getap village of Vayots Dzor region

loans.name: Shpresa

texts.en:
Shpresa, whose name in English means Hope, is married and has three children. She has been in the agriculture/livestock business for almost 10 years, which has been the only source of income for the family. 

Shpresa is requesting a loan, which she will use to repair her animals' stable.

loans.use: to repair the existing stable

loans.name: Adama

texts.en:
Adama is 32 years old and married, with three children. She runs a fish business in Tombo, a western, rural area in Sierra Leone. She started this business to get her daily living. 

She went into this business just after she got married, selling fish within her community. She says that, at present, her business is doing well because, out of the profit, she was able to take care of her family.

Adama requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone Microfinance Company Limited, to purchase more fish for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and pay her loans. 

In the future, she would like to expand her business to a higher level. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is in her early 30s, married, and has three children. She runs a cosmetic business in Tombo, the western rural area in Sierra Leone, selling perfume, toothpaste, and cream at a busy market area. She began her business because she wants to strive for her daily bread. The main problem in her business is lack of capital to expand.

Fatmata is requesting a loan from BRAC Sierra Leone, which she will use to buy cosmetics such as perfume, toothpaste, and cream to sell. The extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, she would like to expand her cosmetics table.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics such as perfume, toothpaste, and cream

loans.name: Ariunaa

texts.en:
Mrs. Ariunaa is 41 years old and lives with her husband and three children in a small house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband, Chuluunsuh, has been helping his wife take care of livestock. Her daughter is a university student, her older son goes to the secondary school, and her younger son stays at home. 

Ariunaa started her organic dairy product production business in 2008 with the help of her husband. Now, she owns 10 cows and produces increased amounts of organic dairy products to sell to local residents. Her business is stable and already has regular customers. She is preparing her cattle to survive through the long, harsh Mongolian winter and is now requesting 3,000,000 Mongolian Tughriks (MNT) to purchase forage and grass to feed her cattle during the winter. She is a hardworking, business-minded, and modest woman.

loans.use: to purchase forage and grass to feed her cattle during the winter.

loans.name: Chrev

texts.en:
Chrev is 55 years old, married, and has four children, three of whom are employed and one of whom attends university. He is a farmer from Prey Kabas district, Takeo province. He owns and manages 50A farmland, on which he usually grows rice to sell. The other source of income is from his wife, who is involved in weaving clothes to sell to local traders or in the markets of the province. 

Chrev’s daughter, Srey Sor is 20 years old, just passed her high school exam this year, and is planning to continue her education in the Faculty of Agriculture Economics and Rural Development at Royal University of Agriculture. She has a passion for her major because she is aware that this major is suitable for her personality. 

Chrev is requesting a loan from HKL, which he will use to pay for his daughter's education fees.

loans.use: to pay for his daughter's education fees.

loans.name: Sidi

texts.en: Sidi is 41 years old, female and married. She has four children, 17,14,10 and 7 years old respectively whom she supports. Sidi was introduced to KADET Ltd by a KADET officer and she runs a grocery business which has lasted for 10 years now. It is located at New Market. In her business, she earns a monthly income of KSH 8,550. She is taking her first loan of KSH 20,000 which she intends to use for adding stock to her business including tomatoes, potatoes, brinjals, pilipili hoho, peppers and cabbages. Sidi will use the anticipated profit to expand her business. Her hopes and dreams for her future business and family are to educate her children and have a bigger business.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tomatoes, potatoes, brinjals, pilipili hoho, peppers and cabbages to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 58 years old. She lives in Yerevan city. For many years, she has worked as a teacher of Armenian Language and Literature at the school. She is a widow. She has a son and a daughter; they are still not married and they live with their mother. Now Mariam runs her own business. On a rented stall, she sells women's underwear. All the products she brings herself from Moscow and Turkey, but sometimes, if it is possible, she makes an order to the company and it sends her ordered products to Armenia. She receives it in a week. In all, she is satisfied of her business income, but she wants to renew it.

Mariam asks a loan of 1,000,000 Armenian drams to bring a new collection of women's underwear from Turkey. Mariam is the best and the most responsible client of Nor Horizon with a rich loan history.

loans.use: to buy a new collection of women's underwear from Turkey for reselling.

loans.name: Blanca

texts.es:
Blanca está estudiando la carrera de administración de farmacia, ella es una persona que quiere salir adelante y poder progresar en la vida, y sabe que la única forma de hacerlo es estudiando.
Cuenta que se esfuerza mucho por poder ser una buena estudiante, ya que también trabaja. Quiere algún día poder tener su propia farmacia y trabajar independiente.
Pide de este crédito para poder cubrir sus gastos de transporte, ya que lleva mucho gasto ello y quiere poder cubrirlo, a la vez que también agradece por esta oportunidad que esta recibiendo.
texts.en:
Blanca is a student in Pharmacy Administration. She is a person who wants to get ahead and be able to progress in her life. She knows that the only way to do this is to study.  She says that it requires a lot of effort for her to be a good student  as she also works. One day she would like to have her own pharmacy and work independently. 

Blanca is requesting a loan to cover her transportation costs, as it is a big expense and she wants to be able to pay it. She is grateful for this opportunity she is being offered.

loans.use: to pay transportation costs to the university.

loans.name: Varsik

texts.en: Varsik is from the village Agarakadzor of Vayots Dzor region. She lives with her husband and his school-age son, who is 16 years old. Varsik is a teacher at the village school. Her salary, however, is not enough to meet her family's needs. To be able to cover her family's daily expenses, Varsik is engaged in breeding a livestock of cows, pigs, hens, and in the cultivation of peaches, apricots, apples, pears and walnuts. Her husband helps her greatly in realizing the agricultural products in the local market. In order for her agribusiness to function in a sustainable way and to be more productive, Varsik needs a loan of USD 2800 to purchase a steer and five piglets. She has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before, but unfortunately wasn't able to return it back. However, thanks to hard work during the recent times, Varsik was able to run her agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that she will be able to cover the monthly payments. So, she has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Varsik and her family will be thankful to all the lenders for helping them to maintain their agribusiness.

loans.use: to purchase a steer and five piglets.

location.town: Agarakadzor village of Vayots Dzor region

loans.name: Elgiza

texts.en:
Elgiza is a first-year student at the American University of Central Asia, department of Business Administration. Below is her story:

“I have graduated from one of the best schools of our country – The Aga Khan School. Now I am happy to enroll at the American University of Central Asia, department of Business Administration. I’ve been thinking of enrolling at AUCA since I first heard about it, when I was in grade 9. I started visiting the AUCA website, following the life of students and the campus. I realized that I can use my knowledge and advance it at AUCA.  I am really happy to be part of this great family.

"One of those opportunities that AUCA gives to all its students is Kiva loans. I need a Kiva loan too, because my family cannot afford to cover the full tuition fees. I would like to thank AUCA and Kiva for such a great opportunity and hope that I will be awarded one.”

loans.use: to pay for my higher education.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past year, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passers-by. She mentioned seasonality as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking oil.

loans.name: Askar

texts.en:
Askar is a student of AUCA, department of Business Administration. Here is his story.

“While we were students at secondary school, we gained knowledge and skills for our future development. I think this education can be used to choose a right path which they go to through one’s life, a well-educated person in the future. For a long time I was thinking about my future work and the person who I want to become, and finally I made a choice. I want to be a specialist who can easily work in the sphere of Business Administration because the education the education and abilities which I received in my school will help me to learn and study Business Administration at American University of Central Asia. 

"AUCA is the best university in our country which gives a higher education to the students and supports them in future. I chose Business Administration department because I want to develop my own business. Studying in this department will give me an opportunity to deepen my knowledge in the fields of Accounting, Management, Marketing and Finance. Having this range of knowledge will expand my opportunities in future. Due to extensive program offered by AUCA I certainly know that after graduation I will have a good opportunity to find job at any area of business. I am sure that all the things which I need from education to be successful in business area I can only gain at the American University of Central Asia. 

"I would like to take an opportunity and apply for Kiva loan, which will help me to cover my tuition fees.”

loans.use: to pay for his higher education.

loans.name: Mbeyu

texts.en:
Mbeyu is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees. 

For the past three years, Mbeyu has operated a shop, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major business challenge. Mbeyu dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With this KES 30,000 loan she wants to purchase salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans, and sweets for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans, and sweets for resale.

loans.name: Luz Lourdes

texts.es: Doña Luz es una señora que como muchos nicaragüenses se dedica a la  pulpería, vendiendo productos básicos para el consumo diario del hogar, ella es madre soltera, en la actualidad tiene a su hijo menor bajo su cargo a quien brinda sus estudios para que se pueda preparar en la vida. Luz para continuar alimentando su pequeño negocio para mantener sus gastos del hogar, solicita el crédito para poder invertir con más productos, ya que carece de inventario, esta inversión le vendrá bien para aprovechar las ventas de estos últimos dos meses los cuales son muy buenos.
texts.en:
Luz is a woman who like a lot of people in Nicaragua own pulperias (small grocery stores). She sells basic daily use items. She is a single mother who right now has her young son in her care. He is studying to prepare for life.

Luz continues to operate her small business in order to pay the household expenses. She is requesting a loan to invest in more products as her inventory is low. This investment would be useful as she can take advantage of the sales in the last two months of the year, which are normally very good.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, cereals and oil.

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en:
Nasiba is a farmer who has a plantation. She has been in the agricultural business since 1998. She sells her agriculture products at the local market. She has a lot of clients who prefer her goods because she grows vegetables of good quality. She hopes that in future years she will develop her business and earn more income. 

Nasiba is a well-bred person and has good knowledge, as she was one of the best pupils in school. Her parents were poor and that is why she couldn’t go on to get a higher education. She always dreamed of being a person with a high degree. 

Nasiba has acquired a loan of 1,000 Somoni to buy building materials such as cement and paint for repairing her house. She awaits your support and believes that your support will make her living conditions better.

loans.use: To buy building materials such as cement and paint for repairing her house

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is a 32-year-old married man. He has three children, ages 9, 7, and 5, all of whom he supports. He was introduced to KADET Ltd by a Kadet officer and he has a retail shop, which is located at Marereni. Emmanuel has been in this business for two years and he earns a monthly income of KES 5,550. 

Emmanuel is taking his first loan of KES 20,000, which he intends to use to add stock to his business by purchasing scones, milk, bread, sugar, salt, wheat flour, maize flour, cooking oil, paraffin, and rice. He will use the anticipated profits to expand his business by making it a wholesale shop. Emmanuel's hopes and dreams for the future of his business and family are to open another business and educate his children.

loans.use: To buy scones, breads, sugar, salt, wheat flour, maize flour, and cooking oil to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en:
Hassan is a married man with four children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past year, Hassan has operated a retail shop, selling to his neighbors and passersby. He mentioned seasonality as his major business challenge. He dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With this KES 20,000 loan Hassan wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil

loans.name: Iskandarbek

texts.en: Iskandarbek is a purposeful young man. He is 25 years old. His father died when he was small. His mother was his only provider. Since his childhood, Iskandarbek has dreamed of becoming a lawyer. Now he is a student of the first course. He studies at the Institute of Social Sciences. He studies with the faculty of law of economic systems. Iskanderbek is trying to realize his childhood dream. He is asking for a loan of 950 USD to pay for tuition. He awaits your support.

loans.use: To pay for tuition

loans.name: Dava

texts.en:
Dava makes woven kilim rugs and decorative pillows, as well as area rugs from old and worn-out clothes.  She does all of this using a primitive type of wooden equipment, as you can see in the picture, which was widely used during the communist era. Dava is from the northern part of Albania, where all the above items are used in every home - it’s the northern tradition. While other women who practiced such activities quit under the new regime, Dava has continued throughout these past 20 something years of democracy and she is happy with her decision because the demand for such items is high now, though mostly from foreign visitors. The items she makes are sold at unique gift stores countrywide.

Dava is 49 and has seven children. She wants to build a little place where she can do her work.

loans.use: to build a room where she can work, making traditional woven kilim rugs and decorative pillows

loans.name: Isha

texts.en:
Isha is 35 years old, married, and has two children who attend school. She is from Tombo in western rural Sierra Leone. In 2009, Isha established her home products business. She began her business because she wanted a source of income to support her home. She works 10 hours a day, seven days a week. The main challenge to her business is the slow purchasing power of her customers.

Isha is requesting a loan, which she will user to buy cups, food containers, and plates to sell. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children and improve her standard of living. In the future, Isha plans to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase cups, food containers, and plates

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha lives in Sinkor. She is 46 years old and she is married. Her husband is out of work. She did go to school. Over the past two years, Martha has been selling soap in the local market in order to help her husband in the home. One challenge she faces is less income. Martha started her business with a small amount of money from her husband when he was working. She says handling some money helps in her home and makes her happy about her business.

Martha is requesting a loan to purchase more soap for her business. She wants to expand her business even more in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more soap for her business.

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en:
Mavluda is a kind woman from a rural area. She has been busy with farming for more than 17 years. Mavluda grows wheat and potatoes. She also has a garden, where she grows apples and pears. Mavluda works hard from early in the morning until late in the evening, seven days in a week. She is the main breadwinner in her family, as her husband is a teacher and earns a small salary. Mavluda has four children. Her family lives poorly in an old house that is in bad condition. 

Mavluda is going to repair her house, but she does not have enough money for the repairs. She is asking for a loan of 1,000 somoni to buy building materials. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy building materials for repairing her house

loans.name: Wangoni

texts.en: Wangoni appreciates his previous Kiva loan, which improved his living standards and enabled him to expand his business and earn a higher income. Apart from his clothes-selling business, Wangoni also operates a food kiosk. He is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil. He thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
Saida is  married and has two children.  She lives in a small village in the north part of her country. The only source of income for the family is from agricultural activities.They have milking cows and sell milk at local markets. It is hardly enough to provide food for the family. 

Saida wants to develop her business but she does not have money to buy more cattle. She is requesting a loan, which she will use to increase the number of cattle. With the profit, she hopes to improve her living condition.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en:
Meet Mariatu - she is in her late thirties and is from Tombo in rural, western Sierra Leone. Mariatu is married and has three  children between the ages of 4 and 13 years old. Her children are currently attending school. In 2009, Mariatu established her timber business. She began her business because she wanted to a source of income to support her household. She works at her business 10 hours per day, 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is that sometimes purchasing by customers is very slow.

Mariatu requires a loan in order to purchase more timber to expand her resale business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children and maintain her family's welfare. In the future, Mariatu plans to open a big shop. She thanks you for your support

loans.use: to purchase more timber to expand her resale business.

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace is very thankful for the financial assistance extended to her. She was able to buy more grocery items for her variety store, which she has been running for four years now. Her loan is also helpful for educating her child. Her income from the business assisted with their everyday household expenses. She and her husband are working hard to provide for their family.
 
She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in greater profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her child’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Mary Grace hopes that her business will be more successful, and she dreams to give her child a good life and education. She meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Sopheap is 32 years old and a married man with two children, who depend on his income. He lives with his family in Kampong Chhnang province. He earns a daily wage by working in the construction industry. He is a builder master who monitors a group of workers at the construction site. Though he has encountered a lot of hardships in his careers and life, Sopheap aims to provide enough for his entire family and to help his children with their educational needs.

Sopheap wants to start settling down in his own accommodations with his children and his wife, so he wants to buy a piece of land for constructing a home. To realize his dream of having a home, he decided to take out a loan of KHR 3,000,000 to supplement his existing money to buy land for housing purposes. Sopheap is very thankful for this constant support, which will allow him to better his living situation.

loans.use: to buy land for housing purposes.

loans.name: Ashot

texts.en:
Ashot is 25 years old and he lives with his mother in Kapan city. After school, Ashot went to Russian Federation (where his father temporarily lives and works) to earn money for his family's needs, but he returned to Kapan for army service. 

Now Ashot has ended his army service and he already works; he is a dyer. Simultaneously, with his own car, Ashot gives taxi service around his city. Ashot’s mother is unemployed and she takes care of their house. The flat where Ashot and his mother live needs to be entirely repaired and Ashot has also decided to get married.

He asks for a loan of 1,100,000 Armenian drams (AMD) in order to begin his flat repairing activities and also to pay for some expenses for his wedding.

loans.use: To begin his flat repairing activities and also to pay for some expenses for his wedding.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is in her late 20s, married, and has three children, two of whom attend school. She lives in Tombo in western rural Sierra Leone. In 2009, Fatmata established her home products business. She began her business because she wanted a source of income to support her home. She works 10 hours a day, seven days a week. The main challenge is the slow purchasing power of her customers.

Fatmata is requesting a loan, which she will use to buy cups, food containers, and plates to sell. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children and improve her standard of living. In the future, Fatmata plans to open a big shop.

loans.use: to purchase cups, food containers, and plates

loans.name: Eline B.

texts.en:
Precisely 40 years old, Eline lives in Sinkor. She is married and has four children between the ages of 1 and 21 years old, three of whom are in school and live at home. Eline is a 10th grade dropout who is now a talented businesswoman from Liberia. According to her, she established her business with a little money from her husband. She has sold charcoal by the bag from Monday to Saturday, spending ten hours each day at her business in the local market for 11 years now. Eline describes herself as a talented businesswoman. She enjoys her business because she has a lot of customers and makes a lot of profit. 

Eline is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal for her business. Her plan for the future is to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia is a married woman with no children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For over two months, she has operated a fruits and vegetables stall, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With this KES 20,000 loan, Sophia wants to purchase more stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes, and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase more stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes, and onions

loans.name: Erlin Maria

texts.es: Gracias al primer financiamiento brindado por la cooperativa COMIXMUL en alianza con los inversionistas en KIVA, Erlin pudo comprar los insumos que sus cultivos de café necesitaban para estar protegidos de plagas entre otros que podían haber perjudicado sus cultivos. Ella compro fertilizantes, abono, foliares con lo que pudo asistir sus cultivos de café pero también parte de estos insumos los destino a una tomatera con la que pudo también asistir 8 tareas cultivadas de tomate logrando obtener una excelente cosecha con la que pudo cumplir con su primer compromiso vendiéndola a muy buen precio en el mercado obteniendo más de lo esperado. ella se encuentra muy agradecida por ser tomada en cuenta por la cooperativa COMIXMUL al brindarle esta clase de apoyo financiero por lo que ella nuevamente ha venido para solicitar un segundo financiamiento con el fin de poder cultivar nuevamente una tomatera e invertir otra parte en sus cultivos de café para que al final de la cosecha poder obtener las ganancias esperadas y seguir gozando de estos beneficios.
texts.en:
Thanks to the first loan granted to her by the COMIXMUL cooperative along with the lenders from Kiva, Erlin was able to buy the supplies that she needed to protect her coffee crops from infestations which might have damaged her crops. She bought fertilizer, manure, foliar sprays to help her crops. Also part of the loan was used for supplies destined for a tomato plot where she grew about 500 square meters of tomato plants. She got an excellent harvest which helped her pay off her first loan. She sold them for a very good price in the market and received more than she was expecting. 

Erlin is very grateful to be considered by COMIXMUL offering her this kind of financial support. She has now requested a second loan in order to once again plant tomato crops and invest another part of the loan for her coffee crops. Then at harvest time she can get the profits she anticipates and continue to enjoy these benefits.

loans.use: to plant a new tomato plot and another part of the loan for her coffee crops.

loans.name: Mayranush

texts.en: Mayranush is from Jermuk city of Vayots Dzor region. She lives with her husband. The two of them work hard to be able to earn a living. Mayranush works as a librarian at the school library, and her husband works in the private sector. However, they cannot afford a living based on their salaries alone. To be able to meet her family's needs, Mayranush is engaged in beekeeping. Her husband helps her sell the honey in the local market. To be able to run the beekeeping business in a sustainable way, Mayranush needs a loan of 1,500 USD to purchase eight new beehives. With the help of the loan, her agribusiness will become more productive. As this is Mayranush’s first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who haven't had access to credit products before, because they have no credit history. Mayranush and her husband will be very thankful to the lenders for their good will and support in providing the needed loan.

loans.use: to purchase eight new beehives

loans.name: Tsiala

texts.en:
Tsiala, age 43, is from the village of Ubisa. She is a widow and lives with her son, daughter-in-law, and an infant grandson. Tsiala works at a restaurant, where she cleans and washes dishes. Her monthly salary is nearly $150.  After work, Tsiala helps her son in running an agricultural business. Specifically, the family breeds five pigs and plans to sell them in wintertime when pork prices are higher.  In addition, Tsiala grows nuts and walnuts in her garden and sells the harvested products locally.

The family income is modest and Tsiala wishes to start a trading business to generate monthly funds. With this start-up loan, Tsiala will purchase a car. She and her son will purchase cheese at wholesale prices in their village and transport the products by car at the neighboring town.  They will sell cheese among retailers with a price mark-up and earn additional income for their family's well-being.

The increased profit will be reinvested in the same business and Tsiala hopes she will be able to improve the standard of living for her family members in the future.

loans.use: to purchase a car and use it in cheese trading

loans.name: Hakob

texts.en:
Hakob is 27 years old and he lives in Gavar city, which is in the Gegharkunik region. Unfortunately, Hakob’s father and mother died several years ago and he lives in their house with his two brothers. His brothers have no constant work; they do construction work around their city. There was a time when Hakob was jobless and he left for the Russian Federation to work abroad, but he came back after several years and decided to establish a farm. 

Now, Hakob has a rich farm, where he keeps five cows, four bulls, four calves, and twenty chickens. He also cultivates potatoes and cabbage, which he sells to re-sellers. Hakob has seriously decided to become a skilled and clever farmer, thus he does everything himself, with great pleasure and enthusiasm. 

Hakob seeks a loan of 900,000 Armenian drams in order to buy two calves and animal fodder for the winter months.

loans.use: To buy two calves and animal fodder for the winter months, which will allow him to receive a good profit from his farming

loans.name: Diane Claire

texts.en: Diane is a 34-year-old Cameroonian who is divorced with four children. Her oldest child is fifteen years old and attends secondary school while the youngest is four years old and is in primary school. She has been in this business for the past seven years. As a result, she is very experienced and her business is very profitable. This business is likely to succeed because it is located in an urban center with many potential customers. This loan will help her increase her profit by 30 percent and her standard of living will increase as well.

loans.use: To buy drinks wholesale for retail

loans.name: Josefa Antonia

texts.es: Doña Josefa, es una mujer muy fuerte, hace pocos meses que enviudó. El hecho de estar sola no es un impedimento para salir adelante, ella continua con sus labores diarias en su pulpería que es la fuente de sustento para ella y su hijo quien tiene capacidades diferentes. Doña Josefa esta vez solicita el crédito para surtir su negocio con nuevos productos de temporada demandado por sus clientes como pollo, carne, mortadela, y otros, que dejaran buenos ingresos en estos meses del año.
texts.en:
Josefa is a strong woman. A few months ago she was widowed. The fact of being alone does not stop her from trying to get ahead. She is continuing with her daily labors in her small store which is the source of her financial support for her and her son who has disabilities.

Josefa is requesting this loan to stock her business with new seasonal products requested by her customers like chicken, meat, sausage, etc. which will generate good revenues in these last months of the year.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, cereals, meat, vegetables, sweets and soft drinks.

loans.name: Sari

texts.en:
Sari is 25 years old and he lives in Gaza. He sells used refrigerators. He opened his small workshop in 2006, and he has good experience. This business is his only source of income.

Sari is satisfied with the income of his business, but he needs this youth loan to decorate his shop. This will increase the number of customers and increase his income, which will help him to improve his financial conditions for the future.

Sari is very grateful to everyone who helps him to achieve success in his business with this loan.

loans.use: to decorate his shop

loans.name: Arkadik

texts.en:
Arkadik is a farmer from the Geghasar village in the Lori region. He lives with his wife and two little sons (six and four years old). 

To take care of his family, Arkadik is engaged in breeding livestock of cows, pigs, hens, and turkeys and in the cultivation of wheat, barley, potatoes, cabbages, and beets. He sells the agricultural products in the local market, which is the only source of family income. 

Since his family’s needs are growing on a daily basis, Arkadik needs to expand his agribusiness to be able to cover the needs of his family. A loan of USD 3,000 will support him greatly, enabling him to purchase three steers, two pigs, and some forage for the livestock. With the help of the loan, Arkadik will sustain his agribusiness. 

He and his family will greatly appreciate the lenders' goodwill and they will be very grateful to them for their help in obtaining the needed loan.

loans.use: to purchase three steers, two pigs, and some forage for the livestock.

loans.name: Mwanahamisi

texts.en:
Mwanahamisi is married and blessed with three children who attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwanahamisi cooks food that she sells at the market to town dwellers and passersby. She cites price fluctuations as a challenge in the business. She dreams of establishing a café business in the future.

With this KES 50,000 loan, Mwanahamisi wants purchase to food ingredients such as beans, rice, wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase food ingredients such as beans, rice, wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a business-minded woman. She lives simply with her husband and three children. Her youngest child attends school, while the other two are out of school. Grace offers cosmetic products, detergent soap, shoes, sandals, and blouses within her locality. Her husband's work is as a driver of a motorcycle and as a farmer. Grace has been engaged in the direct-selling business for more than five years.

Grace would like to improve her direct-selling business, but she does not have enough capital. With regards to her situation, she decided to ask for a loan of PHP 35,000, which will allow her to buy stocks of cosmetics, short pants, blouses, and some raw materials for soap making. Grace hopes and prays for approval of her requested loan amount, so she can give her family a comfortable lifestyle and educate her youngest child.

loans.use: to buy stocks of cosmetics, short pants, blouses, and some raw materials for soap making

loans.name: Mbodze

texts.en:
Mbodze is a married woman, and she has six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past two years, she has operated a retail kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 loan, she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking  oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans, to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase foods to sell at her kiosk, including bread, milk, and beans.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is in her late thirties and she is married with three children between the ages of 4 and 11 years old. She runs a fish business in Tombo, a rural, western area in Sierra Leone. Esther started this business to earn a daily living. 

Esther has been in this business since just after she got married and she sells fish within her community. She says that at present her business is doing well because, with the profits, she has been able to take of her family.

Esther requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more fish for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and pay her children's school fees. In the future, she would like to expand her business to a higher level. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Lilliam Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Lilliam, depende únicamente de su pequeño negocio de pulpería, que ha logrado formar con muchos esfuerzos y sacrificios, con sus ingresos equilibra los diferentes gastos de su hogar. Ella es madre soltera que lucha a diario por su familia. Lilliam es una mujer con muchos sueños y aspiraciones. En el futuro desea establecer un comedor para ayudar a los menos desfavorecidos. Esta vez solicita el crédito para invertir en el negocio comprando productos alimenticios de mayor demanda por sus clientes y los vecinos del barrio donde habita. De igual manera diversificará la variedad de cosméticos los cuales vende en el mismo negocio.
texts.en:
Lilliam depends completely on her small store to generate the revenues which she uses to pay off the household expenses. She set it up through much effort and sacrifice.
