She is a single mother who fights daily for her family. Lilliam is a woman with many dreams and ambitions. In the future she would like to open a cafe to serve the underprivileged. 

Lilliam is requesting this loan to invest in her business buying food products most requested by her customers and neighbors in the area she lives in. At the same time she will diversify the variety of cosmetics  that she also sells in her store.

loans.use: to buy basic grain products, sausages, cereals, milk, meat, eggs and cosmetics.

loans.name: Narine

texts.en:
Narine is 39 years old and she lives in Gavar city, which is in the Gegharkunik region. She is married and has two sons who are already drafted into the army. Narine’s husband is in the Russian Federation and he does construction work there in order to support his family financially. Narine, completely alone, is engaged in farming and she has on her farm three heifers and four calves. She mainly sells meat to the local butchers, but she would like to sell milk also, which would increase her farm income.

Narine seeks a loan of 500,000 Armenian drams in order to buy a cow and also some animal fodder for the winter.

loans.use: to buy a cow and also some animal fodder for the winter

loans.name: Jeniffer

texts.en:
Jeniffer expresses appreciation for her previous Kiva loan. The loan improved her living standard, by enabling her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

Now, she is requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 50,000 KES. She will use the loan to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Sona

texts.en:
Sona lives in the very beautiful city of Dilijan, which is in Tavush region. She is married and has two daughters. Her husband used to work as a policeman, but now he is retired and, at this moment, works as a driver at a private company. Sona’s family are friendly, and all together, they are engaged in farming and agriculture. 

They have in their farm two cows and two calves. The dairy products that their farm cattle give are milk, cheese, butter and meat. Sona manages to sell with the help of her neighbors and relatives who know her.
 
Sona asks for a loan of 250,000 Armenian Drams in order to buy one more cow, and in this way, enlarge her family income and increase her farm.

loans.use: to buy one more cow to enlarge her family income and increase her farm.

loans.name: Mamusu

texts.en:
Meet 30-year-old Mamusu from Tombo, in rural, western Sierra Leone. She is married and has three children between the ages of 2 and 12 years old. Two of her children are currently attending school. In 2009, Mamusu established her home product sales business. She began her business because she wanted to earn her daily bread. She works at her business 10 hours per day, 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is high completion in her business.

Mamusu requires a loan in order to buy cups, food containers, and plates for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children and improve her standard of living. In the future, Mamusu plans to open a big shop. She thanks you for your support

loans.use: to buy cups, food containers, and plates for resale

loans.name: Saffinatu

texts.en:
Meet 35-year-old Saffinatu from Tombo Western rural area in Freetown. She is married with 2 children, ages 1 and 6 years old. After the war, Saffinatu established her pharmacy business. She began her business because she needs to help her community through medical care. She works at the business 10 hours per day and 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is lack of enough capital to run it.

Saffinatu requires a loan in order to buy more medical drugs, such as malarial drugs, blood syrup, and cold syrup, for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her standards of living. In the future, Saffinatu plans to own a big shop. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more medical drugs, such as malarial drugs and blood and cold syrups, for resale.

loans.name: Abida

texts.en:
Abida is 39 years old and married. She has been successfully operating a small general store with her husband at the corner of their house, which she has been doing for three years.  Her husband also assists her by purchasing stocks of goods from the market as he has maintained many contacts over the years. 

Abida wants to expand her business so she is requesting a loan for 30,000 PKR, which she will use to buy packs of salts, biscuits, and beverages to meet the increasing demand at her store. She is motivated to provide her family with good quality food, clothing, and health. She is expecting a boost in her earnings and dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase packs of salts, biscuits, and beverages.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is an experienced farmer from Vanadzor city, in Lori region. He has a big family, which includes his wife (in the photo), two daughters (20 and 19 years old), and four sons (14, 12, 9 and 6 years old). Robert's younger daughter works in the flower shop. To be able to take care of his big family, Robert is engaged in breeding livestock - sheep, pigs, and hens - and in cultivating walnuts. He realizes income from selling the agricultural products in the local market.

As the autumn is progressing, Robert needs to make some investments in his agribusiness. A loan of USD 1000 will support him greatly, enabling him to purchase forage for the livestock. He has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before, but unfortunately wasn't able to pay it back. However, thanks to the hard work during more recent times, Robert has been able to run his agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that he will be able to cover the monthly payments. So he has now been approved for a loan, within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF International. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history and have no access to credit products. Robert and his big family will be thankful to all the lenders for helping them to maintain and develop their agribusiness.

loans.use: to purchase forage for the livestock

loans.name: Rosine

texts.en:
Rosine is a middle-aged Cameroon woman. She is forty nine and married with two children; the oldest is 19 and in high school, and the youngest is in secondary school. 

She has been in this business for over a year now, which makes her successful and her business stable. She is likely to succeed because her business is located in an urban area with so many potential customers. This loan will help her increase her turnover by 50 percent, and her living standard will also improve.

loans.use: to buy raw food to cook and resell and soft drinks to resell.

loans.name: Sadia

texts.en: Sadia is 33 years old and married. She has been running a small general store in her community for many years with the support of her husband. She offers a variety of grocery items at a reasonable price and has retained many customers who regularly shop at her store. Sadia makes enough to provide for her family. To make sure her store is fully stocked, she requested a loan of Rs 25,000, which she will use to buy rice, sugar and flour from the market at lower rates. In this way, she will be able to meet the increasing demand consistently. Sadia wishes to use part of her revenues to increase her business capital.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar and flour to sell

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Rachel continues operating her tailoring business, making garments for both men and women. She cites seasonality as her major challenge, and she dreams of establishing a big tailoring shop in the near future.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans, to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business.

loans.name: Benjamin's Group

texts.en:
In Ivola village, Kenya, Benjamin has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Benjamin is a friendly 73-year-old member of the community, and he has 12 children. Benjamin lives with his family in a house with concrete walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof. He is a subsistence peasant farmer, his primary crops being maize and cassava. He actively participates in community prayer groups. 

Ivola village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Benjamin and the 15 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Benjamin has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Benjamin volunteered to be the promoter because, in his own words, "I love my people!" He wants to help the community by killing germs in drinking water and improving health. There are also three other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Phoebe, Josephat, and Florence.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Benjamin’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Shahnaz

texts.en:
Shahnaz, 32 years old, is a very enthusiastic person. She has been successfully running a general store for a period of about six years. She offers a variety of daily use products and has a good client base.

In order to avoid shortages, Shahnaz needs to have various goods in stock to efficiently meet customer demand. She has requested a loan of PKR 30,000, which she will use to buy additional grocery items, including oil, milk, sugar, and juices. In this way, she will be able to consistently meet the increasing demand at her store and make better earnings.

She is in her fifth loan cycle and has shown good repayment behavior. She hopes to grow her business, and to better support the needs of her four children.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery items to sell, including oil, milk, sugar, and juices

loans.name: Mikhail

texts.en:
Mikhail is a young agronomist from Kapan city of Syunik region. He lives with his elderly pensioner grandmother. Mikhail works in the private sector. He is employed by two companies, and works hard to be able to earn a living. He is also engaged in beekeeping, which is an important source of income.

Mikhail realizes the honey in the local market. As life is getting more expensive with time, Mikhail wants to expand his agribusiness to be able to effectively meet his family's needs. A loan of USD 3,000 will support this young hard-working man, enabling him to purchase 25 beehives and the necessary materials for beekeeping (e.g., special medications and some wax). 

He has already taken a loan from a local financial institution before, but unfortunately, wasn't able to return it back. However, thanks to the hard work during the recent times, Mikhail was able to run his agribusiness in a sustainable way, ensuring that he will be able to cover the monthly payments. So, he has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The second-chance loan program provides loans to people who have a bad credit history, and have no access to credit products. Mikhail and his grandmother will be thankful to all the lenders for their goodwill in helping them collect the needed loan.

loans.use: to purchase 25 beehives and the necessary materials for beekeeping (e.g., special medications and some wax).

loans.name: Andranik

texts.en:
Andranik is from Kapan city of Syunik region. He lives with his wife. Andranik works in the private sector as a clerk, and is the only breadwinner of the family. His salary alone, however, is not enough to meet his family's needs. To be able to fully meet his family's needs, Andranik is engaged in cattle breeding, aviculture, and beekeeping. He realizes the agricultural products at the local market. 

Farming is an important source of income for the family. To continue running his agribusiness in a sustainable way, Andranik needs a loan of USD 3,000 to purchase two cows and several beehives. The loan will make his agribusiness more productive. Andranik and his wife will be very thankful to all the lenders for helping them collect the needed loan to maintain and develop their agribusiness.

loans.use: to purchase two cows and several beehives.

loans.name: Edinson Angel

texts.es: El cliente reside en el sector de Orquídeas en Guayaquil.  Empezó realizando carras en aun auto pequeño, posteriormente adquirió un taxi amarillo.  Ahora trabaja en él y le da la libertad de llegar a su casa para almorzar y también cuidar a su mamá, pues viven juntos.  Trabaja solo, todos los días.  No es casado y por ahora no tiene hijos.  A futuro desea terminar de construirle la casa a su mamá.  Ahora requiere el crédito para la compra de llantas y repuestos para el arreglo de su vehículo.
texts.en:
This borrower resides in the Orquídeas sector of Guayaquil.  He started making trips with a small automobile, but he later acquired a yellow taxi.  He now works with this vehicle and has the freedom to go home for lunch.  The borrower also takes care of his mother since they live together.  He works alone every day and is not married.  At the moment, he has no children.  In the future, he wants to finish the construction of his house for his mother.  

For now, the borrower is requesting a loan in order to buy tires and spare parts so that he can repair his vehicle.

loans.use: to buy tires and spare parts for his taxi.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes was 18 years of age when she started working as a manicurist within her local community. She is widowed and blessed with five children. Four of her children had settled for marriage while the other child is her companion in her home service manicurist and beautician business. 

Mercedes aims to have her own beauty salon within the market of Cordon. So for now, she's doing her very best in order to earn greater income and to satisfy her customers' demands. In this way, she could encourage more customers. 

This time, Mercedes wants to buy a new blower, an iron for hair, and necessary chemicals for hair re-bonding and cold wave, but she doesn't have enough capital. Therefore, she is seeking additional capital, amounting to PHP 22,000. She hopes to obtain this amount of loan, so she could sustain her family's basic needs and save some for emergency purposes.

loans.use: to purchase a new blower, an iron for hair, and chemicals for hair re-bonding and cold wave, which will be used for her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Walter's Group

texts.en:
In Gamalenga village, Kenya, Walter has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Walter is a friendly, goal-oriented, hard-working, and reliable member of the community with a 14-year-old son and a 2-year-old daughter. Walter lives with his family in a house with concrete walls, concrete floor, and an iron roof. He is a secondary school teacher and he is an active member of a credit savings group in his community. 

Gamalenga village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Walter and the 20 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Walter has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Walter volunteered to be the promoter because he was chosen by other community members and he wants to help the community to reduce costs of treatment, hence improving living standards. There is one other volunteer promoter from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Taphroza.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Walter’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Joash's Group

texts.en:
Joash is 79 years old, has 8 children ranging from 20 to 43 years old, and he lives in Boyani village in Gamalenga, Kenya. Boyani village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected dug well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria and viruses that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Joash and his family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school. 

Joash has a primary school certificate and works as a subsistence/peasant farmer. He has generously volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Joash and other promoters in his community (including Thomas) need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Joash will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and will refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Joash wants to be a promoter because he believes that the dispenser will kill germs in water and make it safe to drink.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Joash’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Emily's Group

texts.en:
In Butiti village in Jivoli, Kenya, Emily has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Emily is a 39-year-old, hard-working, well-known member of the community with no children. She lives in a house with concrete walls, a concrete floor, and an iron roof. She is active in several community groups, including a women's savings group and a burial committee. 

Butiti village does not have a piped water supply, so the community members collect their water from a protected dug well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria and viruses that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Emily and the 55 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Emily has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. She volunteered to be the promoter because she is a hard worker and she wants to help the community improve its overall health. There are also three other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Susan, Luka and Febe. 

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Emily's community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Judith's Group

texts.en:
In Bumavi village in Jivovoli, Kenya, Judith has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Judith is a friendly, hard-working, trustworthy, well-known and well-liked member of the community with 5 children. Judith lives with her family in a house with mud walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof. She is a subsistence peasant farmer, primarily cultivating potatoes and maize. 

Bumavi village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a unprotected well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Judith and the 10 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Judith has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Judith volunteered to be the promoter because she wants to make sure people are healthy in the community and help the community by preventing water-borne diseases. There are also four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Florence, Beatrice and Albert.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Judith’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Zabida

texts.en:
Zabida is a 48-year-old married woman. For the past three years, she has been successfully running a small general store with her husband at the corner of her house. Her husband also assists her by purchasing stocks of goods from the market, as he has maintained many contacts in years. 

She is the mother of three children, and is motivated to provide her family with good quality food, clothing, and health. She wants to grow her business, so she requested a loan of PKR 25,000 to buy packs of salts, biscuits, and beverages to meet the increasing demands at her store. She is expecting a boost in her earnings, and dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy packs of salts, biscuits, and beverages.

loans.name: Kousar

texts.en:
Kousar is a 44-year-old married lady. She has been stitching clothes for many years. She stitches for the people in her community, and uses the income to support her entire family. She is also involved in work of hand embroidery to generate extra amount of income. 

But, due to lack of availability of funds, she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. For this reason, she requested a loan of PKR 20,000 from Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan amount to buy more spools of threads in different colors, with the packs of laces, zippers, and buttons. It will help her stitch up more dresses without delay. She is hopeful to get a boost in her earnings, and wishes to spend part of it on the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: to buy more spools of threads in different colors, with the packs of laces, zippers, and buttons.

loans.name: Emelia's Group

texts.en:
Emelia is the leader of this group. She is married, and has three children. She lives in the coastal part of Ghana, where business is very active and profitable. Emelia has been selling smoked fish for 20 years. She hopes that this loan will help her to expand her commerce. She says that her main challenge is to become a bigger merchant, but she is working hard to do that. Her main goal is to have the largest business in her area. 

Other members of this group have need of a loan for businesses selling fish and other foodstuffs.

loans.use: To buy fish to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Las Talentosas Group

texts.es: Yesenia tiene 23 años es soltera con hijo de 4 años hace 19 años que trabaja juntamente con su familia en la venta de juguetes años atrás se dedicaba al cuidado de su hijos ser parte del grupo “LAS TALENTOSAS” le ha permitido crecer económicamente junto con su familia. El préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de nuevos juguetes novedosos. El grupo agradece a los inversionistas KIVA por el préstamo brindado. Yesenia es la primera del lado derecho.
texts.en:
Yesenia is 23 years old, single, and has a four-year-old son.  She and her family have been in the business of selling toys for 19 years, which enables her to take care of her child.  

Yesenia is part of the group “Las Talentosas” (The Talented Ones), which enables her to grow financially along with her family.  Her loan will be invested in the purchase of new toys.  The group is grateful to the Kiva lenders for providing this loan.  Yesenia is the first person on the right side of the photo.

loans.use: to buy new toys to sell.

loans.name: Salimu

texts.en:
Salimu previously accessed a loan that she used to add more stock of fruits and vegetables for her business. Her earnings were a big help for her personal, household, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for a loan of Kshs 50,000 to purchase stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes, and onions. THe profit from her business will definitely help her to provide for her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with happiness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to purchase stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes, and onions.

loans.name: Shakeela

texts.en: Shakeela is a 29-year-old, married, vigorous lady. She has been stitching clothes for many years. She stitches for the people of her community, and uses the income to support her entire family. However, due to lack of availability of funds, she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. For this reason, she requested a loan of PKR 20,000 from Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan amount to buy more spools of threads in different colors, with packs of laces, zippers, and buttons to create a means for increasing revenues, so she may generate healthier source of income. She dreams of expanding her business in the near future.

loans.use: to buy more spools of threads in different colors, with packs of laces, zippers, and buttons.

loans.name: Mary-Magdalene's Group

texts.en:
Mary-Magdalene is a widow. She is 58 years old and completed the six years of primary education. She makes her living selling detergent and foodstuffs. She started this business with the help of her auntie so many years ago, and she has already spent nine years working in the business.

She heads a group and is seeking a loan to increase her working capital, by buying more detergent and foodstuffs to stock the business. In the future, she hopes that her business will flourish and she wants to have a fixed stall at the metropolitan market. The other members in the group make their living in sales.

loans.use: To buy more detergent and foodstuffs to stock her business.

loans.name: Isata

texts.en:
Isata is 20 years old and single. She runs a fish business in Tombo, a western rural area in Sierra Leone. She started this business to provide daily living for her family. 

She has been in this business since right after she was married and sells fish within her community. She says that at present her business is doing well because out of the profit she was able to take of herself and her parent.

Isata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more fish for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and create income to take care of her pregnancy. In the future, she would like to expand her business to a higher level. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale.

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Meet 25-year-old Isatu from Tombo, a western rural area in Sierra Leone. She is married with three children between the ages of two and eight years old. One of her is children is currently attending school. In 2009, Isatu established her home product business. She began her business because she wants to get a source of income to support the home. She works at the business 10 hours per day, seven days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is sometimes the purchasing power of customers is very slow.

Isatu requires a loan in order to buy cups, food containers, and plates for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, Isatu plans to open a big shop. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy cups, food containers, and plates for resale.

loans.name: Cornelius' Group

texts.en:
Ihedwe village in Kalwani, Kenya does not have a piped water supply, so community members collect their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Cornelius and the 40 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Cornelius is a 62-year-old peasant farmer, and he has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. He volunteered to be the promoter because he was chosen by community and wants to help the community by providing access to safe water. There are also four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Isaiah, Joseph, Maureen, and Nathan.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Cornelius’ community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Raul

texts.en:
Raul is a farmer and lives with wife Eloisa and his three sons.  Every morning Raul gets up before the sun comes up to work in the field.  He plants tomatoes, cactus and cucumber in Totolapan, Morelos.  Meanwhile, Eloisa stays home cleaning, cooking, and taking care of their younger child who is just 4 years old.  Their hard work earns them roughly $550 USD a month.  

Raul has worked hard for over 30 years and has been able to build a home for his family.  Recently, two bedrooms were added on the second floor, but there are some technical issues that were not considered and they need to make some urgent reinforcements before everything they have worked for crumbles down.  Before this expansion, the whole family used to live in a single bedroom; now the children sleep in their new room with just mattresses and no windows.  

This loan will help him make the payment for the materials needed to finish the construction and get expert supervision to ensure that all the investment on the second floor will last for years.  Raul has no access to credit with other organizations because he has an informal job that does not pay much and has irregular cash flows.  The whole family will work together to build this addition to their home.  They will receive supervision visits from certified technicians to monitor the quality and progress of the construction, and to prevent them from losing all the time and money they have already invested.  In less than 3 months, Raul, Eloisa, and the kids will be able to live in a better house with proper structure, windows and floors.

loans.use: to reinforce the structure of the second floor and finish building

loans.name: Hilda's Group

texts.en:
Hilda is 27 years old and has 4 children, and she lives in Sigongo village in Cheptulu, Kenya. Sigongo village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Hilda and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school. 

Hilda is active in the community, participating in a credit savings group. She works as a subsistence/peasant farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Hilda and other promoters in her community (including Phanise, Moses, and Brian) need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Hilda will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Hilda wants to be a promoter because she lives near the water source and is willing to serve the community to reduce the prevalence of diseases. Hilda believes that the dispenser will will help reduce diarrhea in the community.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Hilda’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Philemon's Group

texts.en:
In Bumavi village in Jivovoli, Kenya, Philemon has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Philemon is a hardworking and trustworthy member of the community with 5 children, aged 9 to 16. Philemon lives with his family in a home with mud walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof.

Bumavi village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from an unprotected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Philemon and the 30 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Philemon has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Philemon volunteered to be the promoter because he doesn't want his people to use unsafe water and get sick, and he wants to help the community. He believes that when people use safe water, they will spend less money going to the hospital because they will get sick less often, and that chlorine kills germs in water thus making it safe for use. There are also four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Lilian, Consolata, Mildred and Iniwolata.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Nazeeran

texts.en:
Nazeeran is a 49-year-old, married woman, and the mother of five children. All of her children are school-going. She has been successfully running a business, selling milk. Her husband is a driver with a low salary income, so she initiated her own business to contribute to the family's income. She has become famous for providing good quality milk in her locality.

To cope with the increasing demand of her customers, she contacted Kashf Foundation and requested a loan of Rs. 30,000. She will use the loan to purchase another buffalo. This will help her to increase her sales, which will ultimately generate more income for her. She dreams of providing a better standard of living to her children.

loans.use: to purchase another buffalo for dairy use

loans.name: Abida

texts.en:
Abida is a 44-year-old married lady and mother of three children. Her husband is a government employee with a low salary income. It was very tough for Abida to manage her household needs with the small income of her husband. Therefore, she decided to help her husband in earning. For this purpose, she started her business of clothing sales, as she buys clothes of different verities from the wholesale market and sells them in her area. 

Now she is playing a very important role for her family. Currently, she requested a loan of PKR 30,000 from Kashf Foundation to buy a wide variety of clothes in different colors and designs to attract more customers and expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her earnings with her loan, and plans to spend part of her profits on the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: to buy a wide variety of clothes in different colors and designs.

loans.name: Samina

texts.en:
Samina is a 37 year old married woman. She is a hardworking mother who is helping her family by providing tailoring services in her community. She has been offering tailoring services for the past ten years. She knows the techniques of stitching very well. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns enough to lead a decent life. 

To help her continue operations of her business, Samina has requested for a loan of PKR (Pakistan Rupees) 35,000 to buy stock of threads, in different colors, along with packs of zippers and buttons. She has been in association with Kashf for three years. In addition to repaying the loan, she will use part of the revenue to deal with personal expenses.

loans.use: to buy stock of threads, in different colors, along with packs of zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Safia

texts.en: Safia is a 58-year-old married woman and works from home as a tailor. She has been in this line of work for 10 years now and is proud to be contributing to her household income. When Safia was not earning, her family was going through a severe financial crisis that compelled her to use her stitching skills in a productive manner. Her husband was the sole bread winner of the family, so Safia felt it obligatory to change her family’s living standards. Her hard work helped her establish a good clientele but she is having difficulty in fulfilling large orders. That is why she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of Rs. 20,000 to purchase a new stitching machine with some spools of thread in various colors. She wishes to spend part of the profits on the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: to purchase a new stitching machine with some spools of thread in various colors.

loans.name: Yealie

texts.en:
Yealie is 40 years old and married with four children between the ages of 15 and 25 years old. She runs a fish business in Tombo, a western rural area in Sierra Leone. She started this business to get her daily living. She has been in this business since right after she was married and sells fish within her community. She says that during the raining season, sales are very slow.

Yealie requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more fish for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and take care of her family's welfare. In the future, she would like to expand her business to a higher level. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale.

loans.name: Kennedy's Group

texts.en:
Kennedy lives in a home with mud walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof in Musembe village in Kipchekwen, Kenya. He is 32 years old and lives with his family, which includes 6 children aged 1 to 16. The community of Musembe village collects their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Musembe’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans, then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from recontamination. In Musembe, 15 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Kennedy has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Prisca, Florence, Dorcas and Hestone.

Musembe village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Kennedy believes that the dispenser will remove germs and improve community health. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Kennedy’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Mafia

texts.en: Mafia is a 47-year-old woman and the mother of four children. She is a hardworking mother who is helping her family by providing tailoring services in her community. She has been doing it for many years and knows the techniques of stitching very well. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns enough to lead a decent life. To help her continue operations of her business, she requested for a loan of Rs. 40,000 to buy threads in different colors and packs of zippers and buttons to meet the increasing demand. She is in her sixth loan cycle with good repayment history. In addition to repaying the loan, she will use part of the revenues to deal with personal expenses.

loans.use: to buy threads in different colors and packs of zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Lubna

texts.en:
Lubna is a 34-year-old married woman. 

For many years, she has been selling spices used in cooking food. She purchases spices in bulk from the wholesale market, and then sells them in packs of various sizes. She has become famous by providing good quality spices in her locality, and earns enough for a decent life. She is a responsible mother of four children and needs to earn more to bear the daily expenditures of her family members. 

So she requested a loan of 25,000 PKR to buy a stock of salt, red chilies, black pepper, and turmeric in large quantities to help her to increase her sales. 

She wishes to use her earned profit on her children’s education and well-being.

loans.use: to buy a stock of salt, red chilies, black pepper, and turmeric in large quantities.

loans.name: Mary's Group

Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Finorah and the 100 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Finorah has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. She wanted to serve as the promoter because she likes working with people and she wants to help the community. There are also four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Emphraim, Beatrice, Joyce, and Phanice.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Finorah's community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water.

loans.name: Dancan's Group

texts.en:
In Jeviriri village in Gasianga, Kenya, Dancan has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Dancan is a 27-year-old, friendly hard-working, reliable, and trustworthy member of the community with a two-year-old child. Dancan lives with his family in a house with mud walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof.

Jeviriri village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from an unprotected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Dancan and the 15 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Dancan, who is already active in a community credit savings group, has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. He accepted his post as promoter because he is happy to see and help people use the dispenser, and he wants to help the community by preventing diarrhea cases. There are also four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Jenipher, Janet, Tabitha and Peter.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Dancan’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Moses' Group

texts.en:
In Gavudia village in Givogi, Kenya, Moses has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Moses is a friendly, hard-working, reliable, trustworthy, and well-known member of the community with 7 children. He is 65 years old, makes a living from subsistence farming, and lives in a house with concrete walls, concrete floor, and an iron roof with his family.

Gavudia village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from an unprotected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Moses and the 20 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Moses has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Moses volunteered to be the promoter because he wants to learn a lot about the importance of treating drinking water and he wants to educate the community about how safe water will prevent diseases. There are also two other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Everline and Caroline.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Moses’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Samina

texts.en:
Samina is a 36-year-old married lady. She has three children, all are school going. Her husband is doing government job and earns insufficient income to support the needs of the family members alone. So Samina started her business of sewing clothes to contribute to the family income. She very well knows the techniques of stitching.

Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. To help her continue the operations of her business, she requested for a loan of PKR 20,000 to buy a stock of threads in different colors, along with the packs of zippers and buttons to meet the increasing demands. In addition to repaying the loan, she will use part of the revenues to deal with personal expenses.

loans.use: to buy a stock of threads in different colors, along with packs of zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en:
Naseem is 27 years old. She is a married woman and the mother of four children. She has been running a business, buying and selling animals, for many years. She buys animals (baby goats and calves) at low prices, brings them up, and sells them near the occasion of Eid-ul-Azha (a religious event in Muslim countries). She has gradually improved her business, with the support of Kashf Foundation.

Most recently, she requested a loan of Rs. 35,000, which she will use to purchase two more calves. She is in her third loan cycle, with a good repayment history.  She hopes to grow her business and dreams of giving a good and quality education to her children, through all her hard work in her business.

loans.use: to purchase two more calves.

loans.name: Ulfat

texts.en:
Ulfat is a 52-year-old, married woman, and the mother of four children. The income generated by her husband is insufficient to cover all of the household expenses, so she initiated her business of milk sales. She has been doing it for many years and has become famous for providing good quality milk in her locality. With the support of Kashf Foundation, she has gradually improved her business.

Recently she requested a loan of Rs. 30,000, which she will use to purchase another buffalo. This will help her to increase her sales, which will ultimately generate more income for her.

loans.use: to purchase another buffalo for dairy use.

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.en:
Ahmed is a 25-year-old married man who lives in Taiz, Yemen. He has a shop where he sells basic grocery products in a small public area. He started his business by working with his dad in a retail shop; that enabled him to save capital to open his general store. In addition to using his business for selling to customers, he also uses it to help older families so they don't have to go to the market in the city. He attempts, as much as possible, to provide for his customers' needs himself. 

Currently, Ahmed would like to expand his business, but the wholesalers hesitate to provide him with the required goods, dealing with him as a lower-class person. This has become a challenge for him.  So, he has applied for a loan of 200,000 YER (Yemen rials) from AMB in order to buy grocery items such as soft drinks, mineral water, etc., for his business. This loan will help to meet the demands of his clientele, bringing in all that they require. In the future, he hopes to expand his business further in order to increase his profit.

loans.use: to buy grocery supplies (items such as soft drinks, mineral water, etc.) for his business.

loans.name: Shagufta

texts.en:
Shagufta is a 28 year old vigorous lady. She has been stitching clothes for many years. She sews for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. 

Due to lack of availability of funds, Shagufta is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. For this reason she has requested a loan of PKR (Pakistan Rupees) 20,000 from Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan amount to buy more spools of thread, in different colors, along with packs of laces, zippers and buttons. With this loan amount, she is hopeful to cater to more customers without delay. She dreams of providing better standard of living for her family members.

loans.use: to buy more spools of threads, in different colors, along with packs of laces, zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en:
Shamim is a 45-year-old married woman and the mother of two children. 

For six years, she has been running a business selling milk. She initiated her own business by buying a buffalo to support her family. With the passage of time, her sales and income have increased. This has all happened due to her courage and determination. 

Because of her work, she is respected in her home. She helps in all family matters, as well as in financial matters. 

She has some savings, and applied for a loan of Rs 30,000 to purchase another buffalo. 

She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

loans.use: to purchase another buffalo.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca, 56, lives with her husband and her two children. During her working life, she has earned a living as an independent merchant, a job she knows because many of her relatives have worked in the field. She has been selling insecticide, soap, starch spray, and dippers. 

Rebecca needs a loan of GHS 1,000 to buy stock from wholesalers to sell to customers in her community. 

She has been earning a respectable income to help her husband with the financial responsibility of the household. Rebecca dreams of making her business grow and strengthening it so it will be recognized in the sector and generate a good income, so that she can take good care of her children. 

In the future, she hopes to give her family better living conditions and her children an excellent education.

loans.use: To purchase insecticide, soap, starch spray, and dippers to sell.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 36 years old, and married with four children. He earns his income through the sale of crops and livestock, and he receives a monthly wage as a Community Knowledge Worker (CKW). Community Knowledge Workers are trusted community members, who provide agricultural data and advice to rural farmers in their local area, including information about the weather, market prices, crop diseases and agricultural tools. 

On his land, Emmanuel grows maize and beans. He also has chickens, pigs and guinea fowl. Emmanuel has served as a CKW for the last two years, and he looks forward to renewing his CKW contract for the next three years. As a CKW, he will use the materials in his business-in-a-box (smartphone, solar charging set, and weighing scale) to disseminate vital agricultural information to the other members of his village, which will help them improve their crop yields and increase their incomes. 

With the additional money he will earn as a CKW, Emmanuel will invest in his farm so that he can grow more crops, and in turn, improve his family's living standards. His biggest dream in life is to one day build a warehouse that can store all of his grain, so he can sell his crops at higher prices.

loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone, solar charging set, and weighing scale so that he can provide vital farming information to his community.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinta is married and has three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past four years, she has owned a food stall business, where neighbours and town dwellers are her potential customers.

With the Kshs 50,000, she wants to purchase a stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour, and cooking fat. 

She dreams of expanding to a modern café in the business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour, and cooking fat

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary is 55 years old, has 6 children, and lives in Mulwevo village in Cheptulu, Kenya. Mulwevo village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Mary and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Mary works as a subsistence/peasant farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Mary and other promoters in her community (including Faith, Amiani, Francis and Wyckliffe) need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Mary will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Mary wants to be a promoter because she is hard-working. Mary believes that the dispenser will chlorine will kill germs and help her community stay healthier.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Mary’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community.

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en:
Susanna lives in Vanadzor city with her small family. She lives with her husband and a son. Her husband works as a taxi driver, and her son, being back from army, is looking for a job. Susanna has a specialty of teacher, and for many years till now, she worked at a school as a teacher for elementary classes. 

She is devoted to her work and in love with children, who are still so young but so clever and nice. Children respect and love her greatly, as well as all the stuff at the school and her colleagues. Susanna also gives paid individual courses of Armenian Language and Literature.
 
Susanna has a practice of pedagogue for those who are already thirty years old, and nobody knows this methodology of teaching like her, but as she likes to say: it is never late to learn, and she always tries to be informed about changes and innovations in methodologies of teaching and learning. 

This is the reason that she asks for a loan of 350,000 Armenian Drams, in order to buy a computer and literature, which will be of great use for her in her teaching process, both at the school and at home.

loans.use: to buy a computer and literature, which will be of great use for her teaching process, both at the school and at home.

loans.name: Sinam

texts.en:
Sinam is a very nice woman, 53 years old. She lives with her family in Vanadzor city, which is in Lori region. She is married and she has two school-aged sons. 

Sinam has a specialty as an accountant and a financier. For many years, she has worked in her specialty, but now she has her own business -- she sells baby clothes, children's clothes, cradles, towels, bedding, covers, etc. She works in a rented stall at the city wholesale market. 

Sometimes she obtains her stall products from Turkey, but mainly from Yerevan wholesale markets, with the help of her husband. Thanks to her kind and positive attitude and service, she has no lack of customers, who often visit her stall. 

Sinam asks for a loan of AMD 1,000,000 (Armenian drams) in order to enlarge her stall assortment and to get prepared for the winter cold season.

loans.use: to enlarge the assortment of clothes and products she sells.

loans.name: Shoghi's Group

texts.en:
Shoghi is 26 years old and has 1 child, and he lives in Kaptum village in Galona, Kenya. Kaptum village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from an unprotected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Shoghi and his family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Shoghi works as a subsistence/peasant farmer, but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Shoghi and other promoters in his community (including Liz, Mary and Phanice) need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Shoghi will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Shoghi wants to be a promoter because he is service-oriented and aspires to change his community for the better. Shoghi believes that the dispenser will create positive change for people's lives by preventing diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Shoghi’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water.

loans.name: Enos' Group

texts.en:
Enos is 71 years old and has 7 children, aged 22 to 45 years old, and he lives in Jemaga village in Galona, Kenya. Jemaga village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from an unprotected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Enos and his family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Enos works as a subsistence/peasant farmer and has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Enos and other promoters in his community (including Christine, Nifreda, Evans and Rebecca) need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Enos will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Enos wants to be a promoter because he believes that the dispenser will prevent children in his community from falling sick.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Enos’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community.

loans.name: Paul's Group

texts.en:
Paul lives with his family in a home with mud walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof in Jedereria village in Shiru, Kenya. Paul has 7 children and works as a subsistence peasant farmer. The community of Jedereria collects their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Jedereria’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans, then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from recontamination. In Jedereria, 30 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Paul has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Salome, Wilson, Grace and Allan. 

Jedereria village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Paul believes that the dispenser will kill germs in the water. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Paul’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Mouhammad

texts.en:
Mouhammad is a married Iraqi client. He is 54 years old and has 3 children. Mouhammad is the only provider of the family.
Mouhammad owns a small shop where he sells make-ups and accessories. He has been providing his family with the profits from this shop since 2006. He has a good experience in this field, and is well-known in the neighborhood, since he is the only accessories seller in the area.

Mouhammad is requesting a loan of 1,500 USD. He will use this loan to install a sunshade and a display window for his shop. Mouhammad is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he may provide his family with better life conditions.

loans.use: to install a sunshade and a display window for his shop.

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
Hasan is from Iraq. He is 56 years old, married, and has 4 children, for whom her works hard to provide all by himself.
Hasan owns a shop where he sells farm supplies and various types for planting seeds. He has been practicing this business since 1999, and has much experience in this field. Hasan has an excellent reputation in the neighborhood, and is respected by many.

Hasan is requesting a loan of 3,000 USD. The aim of this loan is to pay the annual rent for his shop. Hasan is aiming to grow his business more so he may make more profits from his business in order to enhance the current life standards of his family.

loans.use: to pay the annual rent for his shop.

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
In Mukuyu village in Ivola, Kenya, Mary has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Mary is a hardworking, well-liked member of the community with 2 children. Mary is 46 years old and lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof. 

Mukuyu village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Mary and the 35 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Mary has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Mary volunteered to be the promoter because she was chosen by the community to serve their interests and she wants to help educate people to improve their lifestyles. There are also four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Rose, Miriam, Josephat and Margret.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Mary’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Margaret's Group

texts.en:
In Gimarakwa village, Kenya, Margaret has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Margaret is a friendly, goal-oriented, reliable and well-liked member of the community with 5 children. She lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof. She is active in several community groups, including a women's group, a prayer group, and a burial committee. 

Gimarakwa village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Margaret and the 25 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Margaret has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Margaret volunteered to be the promoter because she thinks that the project is good and she wants to help the community by preventing diarrhea. There are also three other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Lawrence, Janet, and Jescah.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Margaret’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Catherine's Group

texts.en:
Catherine, who is 48 years old and has 7 children, lives in a home with mud walls, concrete floor, and iron roof in Kapkoi village in Kipchekwen, Kenya. The community of Kapkoi village collects their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Kapkoi’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans, then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from recontamination. In Kapkoi, 22 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Catherine has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Francis, Bryson, Emily and Mary. 

Kapkoi village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Catherine believes that the dispenser will improve the overall health of her community. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Cathrine’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 33 years old, married, and has four children. He operates a posho mill in Marereni, which he has been doing for two years. At his mill, he runs a grinding machine that crushes maize into maize flour. He earns a monthly income of 5,550 KES. 

Francis is requesting his first loan from KADET for 10,000 KES, which he will use to purchase more maize. He will use the anticipated profit to expand his business by making it into a depot. His hopes to open another business and educate his children.

loans.use: to purchase maize for his mill

loans.name: Valensia

texts.en: Valensia appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income that she used for her food stall. She wants to start a new business of selling fish in her cafe business. She would like to apply for a loan of KES 50,000 to buy a stock of fish for the business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy a stock of fish for the business.

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en: Benjamin lives in Eldoret. He is a farmer and has been doing this work for 24 years. He has a plot of land where he grows crops and rears dairy cows and poultry. His main source of income comes from the sale of milk, eggs and crops. He says that the most enjoyable part about farming is milking his cows, but the major challenge comes in controlling pests and diseases. Benjamin said that he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan because they cater to the needs of small scale farmers. After the microfinance training done by Juhudi, Benjamin appreciates the fact that in order to progress well in business there has to be good recordkeeping of all transactions. This loan will enable him to purchase more poultry and this will mean egg production will increase and thus income will increase, therefore giving his family a better living standard.

loans.use: To purchase poultry.

loans.name: Yasmeen

texts.en:
Yasmeen had a difficult time after her husband's business failure so she initiated her work of sewing clothes to support her family for a better future. She has two years of experience in this field. 

Yasmeen sews for the people living around her house and uses the income to support her entire family. However, due to lack of availability of funds she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. For this reason she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of PKR (Pakistan Rupees) 35,000 to buy raw material including cloth, threads of different colors and packs of laces and zippers. She is currently in her 3rd loan cycle and has shown good repayment behavior.

loans.use: to buy raw material including cloth, threads of different colors along with packs of laces and zippers.

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en:
Shamim is a 44 year old vigorous lady. She has been stitching clothes for many years. She stitches for the people of her community and uses the income to support her entire family. 

Due to lack of availability of funds, Shamim is unable to meet with the daily demands of her customers. For this reason, she has requested a loan of 10,000 Pakistan Rupees (PKR) from Kashf Foundation. She intends to use this loan amount to buy more spools of thread in different colors along with packs of laces, zippers and buttons. It will help her to meet the demands of her customers without fail. She expects a boost in her earnings and wishes to spend it on the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: to buy more spools of threads in different colors along with packs of laces, zippers and buttons.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 30-year-old Fatmata from Tombo Western rural area in Freetown. She is married and blessed with 2 children between the ages 5 years and 11 years old. She started this business to get their daily food out of the cookery sales. 

Fatmata runs a cookery business at home. She sells cookery food at her house. She started running this business after the war. She works at the business throughout the week, from morning to night. Fatmata says that the main challenges to her business are price inflation and insufficient finances to expand her business.
